I see these Stewart Freeze Dried Liver treats are US made of US inspected beef liver with no preservatives or additives which made me decide to try them with my dogs (I won't purchase foreign made food/treats since my parent's dog became seriously ill a few years ago with the melamine contaminated dog food from China).  My first test of being locally made was met, and the dogs gave them the second test which was whether they liked them or not.  Since they clearly love them, I will be buying more of these treats and I would recommend them to other dog owners to give them a try.

I was pet sitting recently and the dog I was sitting for had these in her treat pouch. She loved them so I tried them with my dogs. All 3 dogs were quite well-behaved whenever they saw me reach for these goodies. My son and I jokingly call them "doggie crack". They're good for them, they work as training tools, what else can you ask for in a dog treat?

My dog loves these and so do I : ).  No yucky texture or greasy feel such as with hot dog pieces or cheese pieces and no grossness in your pocket or treat bag.  And my dog will do a lot for a taste of these treats.

I've been using these for my puppy with training and he absolutely loves them.The only inconvenience I find is that, while each piece varies greatly in size, they are pretty large.  So, I cut them up into pieces appropriate to the size practical for training.  Each time he gets one it is just a little piece, and that works great.Since I do cut them up, I don't find these to be expensive at all because they really go a long way.The other important thing is the list of ingredients.  They are not full of junk.  In fact, there is NO junk in them.  Just beef liver.  I like that, as I really try to know that I'm giving him good quality foods and treats.

My dog loves Stewart Freeze Dried treats. The packaging it comes in is reliable and it preserves the "freshness" of the food. It comes in a big container and there are A LOT of treats in there. Will be buying more soon!

Our holistic vet emphasized the importance of feeding  this along with the home-cooked meals for our lab. I used to buy this at the local pet store but have switched to Amazon due to convenience. The product is easy to use and needs no refrigeration.  Plus, I use it as a training treat for my other dogs.
summary: This is not only a great treat, but nutritious as well

reviewText: Picky eater puppy loves these and makes training easy

These are a great deal when compared to the small bags of treats available at the pet store. More importantly, my dog adores them. I use them as an extra special treat, usually just for when he goes into his crate. As soon as he notices that I have one in my hand, he runs to his crate and waits, tail wagging. The only downside is that the liver cubes smell horrible (to humans, anyway) and leave a powdery residue behind. But as some other reviews have noted, the powder is great for sprinkling on dry food for a finicky dog.
summary: Love these... or at least my dog does.

reviewText: My dog trainer recommended this to our obedience class. I found the best price here on Amazon, and my puppy LOVES the treats. Great training treats if used in moderation (too much organ meat isn't good for anyone). Also excellent if you put some of the treats in a container with non-liver treats/cookies. Use the container as a shaker to help train your dog to come, and the other treats get a liver flavored (dust) coating that makes your dog love them even more! No limit on liver dusted treats!Two paws up for this stuff!

My three month old Westie loves this treat. The only bad thing is that it's huge for training. If I command sit, it takes him 20 seconds to finish eating it and do the next trick. I recommend breaking it into tiny pieces because the label says 1 or 2 a day only. My pup loves this treat and would do anything for it!
We've been using this brand for years.  The beef is far easier to handle than the chicken.  On the hierarchy of treats, this one most reliably gets their attention. :-)
These are great liver treats and the dogs love them. I buy them all the time and will continue to do so!

This is a great treat for dogs, but do read the label: dogs of certain sizes can only have so many of these per day. I violated this and my dog got an upset stomach, so I am just giving a heads up. The cost is a bit high for these treats, but you get a lot of you buy the largest tub. My dogs go crazy for them too!

These treats are 100% beef liver--nothing else. You can't ask for anything healthier than that! Just don't overfeed them. They're treats, not food. Remember that. Your dog would prefer you forget that distinction, because he will love them that much. If you have a small white dog you are probably familiar with the red eye stains. Most people don't know that adding liver to their diet every day will get rid of that ugly stain. Don't exceed the recommended amount. The stain that's already there won't go away, it will have to grow out and be trimmed away by your groomer. But in a few weeks you should notice that white hair is growing in at the base of the old stains.
summary: Great liver treats-extra benefits for white dogs

reviewText: My dogs go nuts over these treats.  Sometimes my one dog decides he is not going to eat his regular food until I add these in and then he gobbles it up.  I have these on hand at all times.

I read sooo many reviews on different dog treats before I purchased any and this was one that seemed to have a lot of high reviews so I went ahead and purchased it, well, my dog isn't the biggest fan, he will only  eat them if there is absolutely nothing else...
summary: didn't live up to the hype

reviewText: My dog loves these treats. They are handy for training but they are dry so water is needed. They are easy to pocket and the crumbs at the bottom make a nice treat over dog food.
My dog never thought it as a treat.  He didn't gobble them up as I expected.  Instead, he would bury them.  Don't know why, but I've learned to trust his opinion.
If you leave you lamps directly on your screen you will be disappointed.  If you clip it onto the cage you will be fine.  This is a mighty powerful light.  I would only use it in winter.
summary: Okay if you're putting this into a clip light it's going to stick out of the clip light

reviewText: I have 5 bearded dragons and I have gone through tons of these.  They are ok with a nice bright light but they never ever seemed to last very long.  The past few months I have been using a small off brand called Solar-Brite and I have had much better results with longevity. They are just not as easy to find.
summary: An ok reptile light for the money.

reviewText: I bought this for my 2 BD and they just sit all day a bask.i will recomend this product to every one who has a desert reptile and its ver affortable

reviewerName: Gin Temoshawsky "I remember having a baby but...
reviewText: This is the light I use for my red-eared slider (an aquatic turtle).  She's a foot long and lives in a heated 120-gallon aquarium.  She loves basking under this light and it really helps keeps her shell nice and healthy by allowing her to completely dry off as she soaks up the rays and warmth.  I keep it on for 12 hours each day but it lasts quite a long time, long enough that I can never even remember the last time I had to change it.
This lamp is just what I expected and was hoping for. Haven't had it long enough to know the life span, but it is certainly doing the job for now. My turtle loves it.

I only rated this product as being OK because it is more of a starter bulb for your reptile until you can get the Powersun bulb. This was the first bulb that I purchased. I used it in the Zoo Med Double Dome lamp fixture during the day-time, along with the 75 watt infrared bulb at night. During this time, I had to dust my box turtle's food with the vitamin D3 Repti Calcium to make sure that she did not develop Metobolic bone disease. It is best to go ahead and get the Powersun bulb if your reptile will be an indoor pet. If you cannot get the Powersun bulb at the time that you get your reptile, just make sure that you get the Powersun bulb within the next two weeks.
summary: Zoo Med Repti Basking Spot Lamp for Reptiles

reviewText: The lightbulb was great, did exactly as described....my cat broke the bulb the first week I had it so I am not sure how it would be long term.

I bought this a long time ago, and I never even opened the shipping box until about a week ago. I've got a sick bird, a small parrot, who needed supplemental heat while she's recovering. So I opened up the package and put it over her tank and she is enjoying the heat. I'm so glad I bought this over a year ago! Great product for all animals.
Went through several other brands, some even burned out after 24 hours! Those have been burning for several months. This is now the brand and source for my lighting needs
I bought this lamp over a year ago and use it for 12 hours every day for my aqua turtles. No problems with it whatsoever. Highly recommended.
The snake loves this lamp. He is kept in the garage which can get rather cool at night. With this lamp he has been rather active and appears quite happy.
Great on keeping tank warm when needed at night time and offers great viewing for your nocturnal pets as well.
This works for the money to keep a reptile tank warm..jopefully it will last, these are known for blowing out quick

I used this bulb while raising my chicks this season. I found the bulb to be quite effective at the job. I did some price comparison at the local pet stores and feed store, the price on Amazon could not be beat. I did not have any issues with the bulb blowing prematurely like some reviewers, however, I didn't use it for longer than two months.

I use these bulbs in a reflecting lamp that sits face down on the wire screen of the terrarium lid. My two pythons can either lay directly under it, or move to a cooler section of the tank. The bulbs tend to last 4 - 6 months, which I consider more than acceptable, since that is longer than many light bulbs last in my house, and taking into consideration the amount of heat that they put out. I highly recommend.

the beardies I have love this.. it lets me shut the main lights off at night and keep heat on without making them stay awake all the timeI keep this on 24/7 and it's performed very well and they love it.

I have this over my fiddler crab tank. It's a 10 gallon. It keeps the tank between 73-80, even if it's down to 64F in the house. Of course, I also have a heater in the water (fiddlers use both water and land) so that also helps with the temp. I would use something with more wattage though, if you have a bigger tank. I've had the light for about 3 weeks now, and have had no problems, but time will tell.

Got two of these and they worked well - kept the heat up and everything as they were supposed to... but then I noticed that when the lights came on to raise the terrarium temperature, my gecko (who is fairly shy) would freeze and not move until the light went out again... I was curious and asked some herp experts WHY this was. Well, they explained to me that though reptiles may not be able to see RED, they can still see BRIGHT LIGHTS so while they would not be able to see, say, a red dress as a red dress, they still notice a bright light popping on periodically. The gecko would freeze when this occured because it was like having an exceptionally bright full moon suddenly shining on them, cause their instinct which tell them that bright light increases the chance of predators finding and eating them to kick in and the gecko to stop moving. I was advised to switch to a ceramic heat emitter which emits NO light which I have since done. The lights are still around in case the heat emitters run in to trouble, but they will be a stop gap rather than a staple.

I have the Zoo Med Double Dome lamp. I use this bulb as a night-time heating source for my box turtle, in conjunction with the 100 watt, Powersun bulb during the day-time. I never turn on both bulbs at once because that would be too much. I have seen my turtle come out and bask on her log as needed while this bulb is on, so I guess she is happy with it. I have had the bulb (and the turtle) for six months. I have had no issues with this bulb so far.
I bought this to attach to the side of my Russian Tortoise's 60gallon rubbermaid tank.  It work well, assembles and adjusts easily.

I boutght two of these for my two tortoises.  They were easy to assemble. The lights hang from them nicely and I like that I can adjust the height.  The bottom plate is not heavy enough to offer much counter-balance, so it must be placed under the tank.  I found the price to be VERY good compared to industrial-type light stand alternatives that I was pricing.  The only reason why I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 is because of the screw mechanism.  In order to assemble and when you want to adjust the height, you screw/unscrew the twist knobs.  These knobs don't actually get screwed into any holes, but just tighten against the inner rod.  To me, over time, these could come loose and cause the hot lights/heater to fall under my basking tortoises.  Of course, this is a worse case-scenerio, but it could happen.  I would have preferred pre-determine holes that the knobs could screw into.  Of course, not having these allows more freedom in regards to height changes.  So it's all relative as to which you prefer.

I used to just set my turtle lamp directly on top of the tanks lid, but I felt like it might be too close to her and I wanted to make it less so.  This is the best way I could think of, but I was hesitant because of the price.  I gets the job done and does it well.

love this lamp stand. easily adjustable and perfect for the over the top tortoise habitat I have going on.the box makes it seem like the "power switch" is somehow connected to the stand no, this is on your lamp. the lamp does NOT come w/the stand ..decently priced product and is holding up nicely. I tend to swing the arm over different areas of the habitat depending on the time of day ..and it's holding up great..

My Beardie's lamp is easier to work around now. I wish the base was a bit steadier without needing to be held down by the tank,. since it gets a little challenging to move the tank.  But it's otherwise very useful, allowing better adjustment of his basking light!

Nice, but perhaps bigger than I need. When placed along the long side of the small aquarium I have, the hook brings the light almost to the far side of the aquarium, rather than near the same side as the stand. Perhaps moving it to the narrow side instead and on the opposite end of the aquarium from where it's needed, the arm will extend long enough so that the light will be where it's needed. But then the cord needs to be strung up more awkwardly for my setup.  My problem, really, not the product's.The stand seems sturdy and designed well. There are clips to hold the cord, but they seem to be made of a metal that isn't particularly springy, so they have to be bent in just enough to grasp the cord, otherwise it tends to slip out. I haven't yet figured out that perfect tension--or perhaps the clips can't maintain it because of the weak metal.
summary: Sturdy and nicely designed but weak clips hold the cord

reviewText: Nice to hanging lamps over an enclosure. Wish the extension was a bit longer and it didn't need to be weighted down to keep it from tipping over but it is still a good product. I have a dozen of them.
Perfect stand with no complains. However aquarium will be slightly tilted when you place it underneath. I still recommend it.

Simple and does it's job. But for my use it extends a little too far out. It would be nice if the arm was about the length of the width of a typical lamp housing for those who need the lamp closer to an edge then the center of the terrarium.Simply made, but not really CHEAPLY made. But they could have put a little more into coating the product as mine has already began to chip from adjusting it's height. Would also be nice to have more user friendly and adjustable cable ties/anchors.
summary: Extends out too much for my use.

reviewText: The metal arms are solid, so is the base, but I don't know why the holes in the metal arms aren't pre drilled to accept the twist screws. It was also perplexing why the one arm was round instead of square, at least the square arms have better grip/traction for the crews. Also mine came with no instructions, and in general came very unprofessionally packed. For awhile I though I had gotten a used/refurbished unit. Also would be better if the wire loop/hook on their deep dome lamp was wider to actually sit in the hook of the lamp stand rather then sit on top of it.
summary: Works as advertised...but it is cheap.

reviewText: These stands are secure and affordable. I use them to hang my Mercury vapor bulbs ($75) from securely. I don't trust the clamp lamps alone!

This is perfect to use for tanks and setups that do not have hoods. The only problem that I had with it is that directions were not included. Once I figured out how it was supposed to go, however, it took like 3-5 minutes tops to set it up.
summary: Zoo Med Reptile Lamp Stand, Full Size

reviewText: This stand is awesome! Sturdy, very easily ajustable and work exactly the way it's supposed too! I would recommend this stand to anyone use uses reptile lighting.

This thing is amazing. You can adjust the height, the angle, the distance into the tank, etc. etc.It holds up my super huge Mercury vapor bulb with ease and has little brackets to secure the wire with.I have so far purchased 2. This is one product where Zoo Med really got it right.
summary: Ingenius! I'm Sure I Could Live Without This Thing if I Had To, But I'd Much Rather Not

reviewText: Use this along with the Zoo Med mini deep combo lamp fixture.  It does a good job holding the fixture over the tank, it is nice and adjustable.  I just wish it would swivel as when I turn it the base slides out from under the tank and I have to be careful that it doesn't fall over.  Otherwise it is perfect and I an happy I got it.
Very durable, bought it with the Zoo Med dome hanging light.  Just make sure you don't put too much pressure when screwing the pieces on.
summary: Puts an ease on hanging lights

reviewText: It's very helpful to hold my lamp just above the tank. Adjustable and just great. Very stable and you can slide the platform right under the tank so it can't move.

This product was pretty much the worst thing I have ever ordered for our terrariums.  The item is made out of cheap metal.  It's "wobbly".  The feet actually press up against the glass on the bottom of the terrarium when you put it in place.  Nothing about this is good.

reviewerName: Ole organic farmer "Micheal W. Adkins SR."
reviewText: It's great to use for your chick brood as you can slide the flat bar under the edge of the chick brooder. It adjusts to the height you need weekly for newly hatched chicks. I wish I had purchased 2!

I use the Zoo Med Reptile Lamp Stand in conjunction with the Zoo Med Mini Combo Deep Dome Lamp Fixture. It works great and I have had no issues so far over the six months that I have owned it. The bottom of the stand slides right under your reptile terrarium. You can adjust the height of the stand (depending on how far or close you want the lamps to your terrarium) and it also has places to clamp the lamp cords.

I have an awesome powerful HOB filter system but it kept sucking up fry and killing snails. I even tried the fry protectors off of another site which didn't kill fry but somehow managed to kill 4 of my mystery snails. I wasn't sure if this would work or even fit but I bought it anyway. This is hands down, the BEST solution out there. It is big so if you have a smaller tank (say 30 gallons or less) it will take up some space. I have a 50 gallon and it works perfect. No more changing out fry gaurds due to debris getting caught. This doesn't clog or slow my water flow and I'm currently using between 2 filters almost 1,000 GPH. I have several snails and fry in my tank so I need extra help. You cannot go wrong with this!!
summary: If I could give it 10 stars I would!

reviewText: Bought this for my aquaclear 30 when my molly had babies to avoid them from being sucked up the filter.  IT worked perfectly, and you can see the bio crud that it traps!  Might actually help the filter increase efficency also.

This prefilter fits to any aquaclear filter you can get. It's very helpful so that you don't really have to unplug your filter since only really tiny tidbits can get through the pores to get into the filter. I recommend rinsing it in some of your leftover water from a water change to keep it 'fresh' to keep the bacteria in. If this is for a new filter, leave it in for a month to get all the bacteria you need on it and if you want, it says that as long as it's been in a tank for 2 months, you can put it in a  new tank to a new filter to establish it immediately.

I have a 55gal planted and dirted tank with small fish, fry, shrimp and a lot of snails. This sponge keeps them from being sucked up into the filter. It is a pain to clean these because if you turn the filter off the gunk stuck to it back flows into the tank, so heres what I do: I take a ziplock bag and place it over the filter sponge then quickly turn off the filter so when the dirt releases the heavy stuff stays in the bag. Then I undo the actual filter "pipe" that its attached to, and remove the whole section. I wash the filter sponge from there. I do not notice any change in flow when using this prefilter when its clean, but of course when it gets gunked up it does impede water flow.
summary: It helps my little tank members....

reviewText: This works great for my fish fry tanks. It lets me keep my hang-off-the-back filters without having to worry that the filter will suck up any of the babies in the tank.

The Filter-Max III Pre Filter was a great buy. I use it as a pre filter on my Aqueon HOB filter. The Filter-Max helps keep the filter clean and allows me to extent the period of time between filter rinses and cartridge changes. This in turn really lets the biological filtration establish itself both in the filter and on the sponge.I like the Filter-Max so much that I have purchased another for my Penguin 200...the only challenge with that will be matching the round pre filter to the rectangular intake on the HOB filter...but I will figure it out!

I used these to modify my Penguin 330 filters to add a "pre-filter".  Just remove the cap on the end and put some of these pieces together until it fits.  Mine sit sideways in the tank.  One pointing to the right and one pointing to the left.  You can position them any way you want though.
summary: I used these to modify my Penguin 330 filters to add a "pre-filter"

reviewText: worked really well with my fluval 406 canister im thinking that they will greatly preserve the integrity of my canister filter media

This add-on prevents baby fish from getting sucked into the filter intake strainer. It also prevents food from getting pulled into the filter before the fish get a chance to eat it. Quality product. Well engineered. High compatibility with most hang on back filters in the market. I have two of these and they both fit in the AquaClear 50 and AquaClear 70 models with the included adapters.
summary: Must have add-on for anyone who breeds fish and has a hang on back filter

reviewText: I bought this to keep baby guppies and cherry shrimp from getting sucked up into the uptake of a fairly powerful canister filter. It has worked very well so far, but it is not quite perfect.I wish the adapter did not have two 90 degree bends in it. This is not great for fluid dynamics, and it also just seems unnecessary - why can't you just put the sponge straight on the tube?Another problem with the adapter is that it leaves small holes around the edge of where the adapter covers the center of the sponge. A wee baby guppy or a baby shrimp could get sucked up in those holes. It would be nice if it fit better.I have had to rub the sides of the sponge once in a while to loosen up the debris and let the water pass better. Its not a big deal, and not a flaw in the sponge, but something to be aware of. You dont want to make your filter pump work any harder than it has to.Overall, its a perfectly good pre-filter, and I am planning on buying another one soon.
summary: Excellent sponge filter, but why the bend in the pipe?

reviewText: good product

reviewerName: Ami Laurie "too young to be grandma"
reviewText: One of those things to have on hand in case ph goes nuts! Does its job.

I bought this when I had just moved to a new place. I hadn't fully tested the water but I knew the pH was way too high. Unfortunately this regulator didn't really work but it was because my carbonate levels were out of control. If pH is your only issue then this stuff will probably be great for you. Just make sure you test your water first.
summary: For people with low carbonate levels

reviewText: My tap has a ph of 8+ and it used to drive me crazy using the acid buffer to try to get it to 7, only to check it a few days later and it was already around 7.5I decided to try this and it works! I do about 1 scoop for every 5 gallons of new water I put in each week and it keeps it right at 7 all week until the next water change.
summary: Just what I needed, better than buffer/acid

reviewText: Did what it said it would. My only complaint is I have no idea what the phosphate is doing in my tank except that algae grows more on glass now and gotta keep up with that. But otherwise it keeps ph solidly at 7.0 even after water changes and temperature changes

If you don't already use this to regulate your pH and de-chlorinate you should. I use 5gallon buckets, and I put in a heaping 1/2tsp and swirl it around with my hand vigorously. It balances pH and softens the water. Most tropical fish will flouish with this product. Just check your fishes kH, and pH tolerances. Seachem has other products you can use in combination to this regulator. Anyone keeping discus should invest in discus buffer by Seachem.

Most acid loving fish will do fine in PH up to 8 if acclimatized.The 2 main causes of fish deaths is an ammonia spike and PH swings from having too low of a dkh.The dkh (carbonate hardness) is far more critical then PH. Most experienced fish keepers keep it at least 5. When dkh gets below 3 a dangerous condition is produced that will likely kill fish. Over time the dkh will fall in your aquarium due to the acids produced in your filter. Water changes or adding an appropriate buffer should be done when the KH falls below a target level.PH is controlled by 3 factors, KH, CO2 and the amount of acid produced in your filter.My tap water has a dkh of 8, I am setting up a tank for a Dwarf puffer. I found these fish do not acclimatize as well as most acid loving fish. This prompted me to experiment with the Neutral regulatorAfter adding a good amount over a period of 3 days I saw little change, I concluded that it is not really great at lowering PH.Next I started with a new batch of tap water and used Acid Buffer to lower my dkh to about 1. I then added some Neutral Regulator and tested my water the next day, The PH was about 7 and the dkh was 6.If your tap water has low dkh it is likely to be low in trace minerals, or If you use RO or distilled water it will lack trace minerals need for fish. In this case you can use an alkaline buffer (commercial or baking soda) or the neutral regulator to raise the KH. You will also need to add trace minerals which will raise the GH.It is important when doing a water change to not make drastic changes in your tank, A change of over .3 ph, more then 2dkh or a change temperature more then 2 degrees F can cause problems.In conclusion I found the best way for me to use this product was to add acid buffer to drop my dkh to around 1 then use the Neutral regulator to make the water stable.What you need to add to your water, if anything, depends on state of your tap water. I highly recommend that you include a KH test as part of your weekly maintenance.

Performing as described, another wonder product from the Seachem laboratories. You can trust nearly everything they place their name on. I haven''t tried all but those I have are good performers, and I will be a repeat owner.

This stuff is great.  It's easy to dissolve in the water and has worked very well with my 2 aquariums.  I add a little extra when I'm just adding water to the tank to help reset the PH of the tank water.

I purchased this product for my 20 gallon freshwater aquarium. My aquarium had been neglected for some time, and the nitrate levels were over 200ppm, GH over 400, and a KH that would hardly ready anything on the test strip. I added an incorrect buffer (too much baking soda) and shot my pH from 6.6 to 8.4, KH went to 300ppm. I need to get these numbers under control.I did several water changes and my GH would only show a slight drop and my KH was not moving. My nitrate levels did decrease with better maintenance of the aquarium.Over the course of 5 days I added 7 teaspoons of Seachem Neutral Regulator. The first day the water turned cloudy and this continued for 2 days. On the 3rd day, I added some AP Crystal Clear water clarifier, which caused the parcipitated calcium and magnesium to clump up and be captured by my HOB filter (AquaClear 50 with pre-filter sponge, biomax, matrix, and foam insert). Each day the pH started to decrease.12-12-11pH: 8.4.Ammonia: 0ppm.Nitrate: 60ppm.Nitrite: 0ppm.GH: 425ppm.KH: 260ppm.After adding Seachem Neutral Regulator from 12-16-11 to 12-21-11 (7 teaspoons total and no water changes):pH: 7.6.Ammonia: 0ppm.Nitrate: 0ppm.Nitrite: 0ppm.GH: 120ppm.KH: 120ppm.Seachem Neutral Regulator softens water, neutralizes ammonia, nitrate, and nitrite.20 gallon high tank, with undergravel filter, and an old penguin biowheel 100 (upgraded to AquaClear 50 on 11-25-2011). Aquarium has been operating for just under 5 years.1- mature angelfish.4- albino cory catfish.3- guppies.4- platies.5- ghost shrimp.Several ramshorn snails.The product does what it says it will do. Although I am currently only at a pH of 7.6, this product is trying to overcome a carbonate based buffer that wants to keep my pH at a high level (8.4). Seachem Neutral Regulator is a phosphate based buffer and had clearly done its job by reducing the pH, GH, and KH.I would buy this product again and recommend it to others. Please keep in mind that a phosphate based buffer can cause algae growth if planted aquariums. My aquarium is planted, but with plants that do well in low light. Higher light levels can lead to unwanted algae growth (as indicated by the manufacturer).
summary: Works well to reduce pH, soften water, and binds ammonia, nitrite, and nitrate.

reviewText: I do not have any fish dying from the water ever since I bought this product and to be honest I don't change the water as frequently as most, so I know this is effective stuff!
I have owned my aquarium for several months now and I have used this product since day. I would recommend this product to anyone with an aquarium. Very easy to use and inexpensive.
summary: helps regulate your ph levels in any aquarium.

reviewText: I slightly overdose this on every water change for all of my tanks, I have over half a dozen bettas, tons of live plants, and several varieties of catfish who are notoriously sensitive to water parameters, and I never have issues.I've never had an issue, despite having hard water and so much chlorine I can smell it. I let the water sit for only a few minutes usually after a stir of prime in.I like to also add StressZyme+ to help keep the weird slime off all of my substrate, plants, and rocks.I prefer SeaChem Prime over any other!I do recommend the small bottle if you keep only a 20g or under as you really wont need more than a 1/4 of a capful for every 5g bucket. It lasts forever.Works wonderfully as "oh s***" ammonia/nitrite/nitrate savers, as well.

I bought this to test out the product, much better than the crap tetra brand I'd used before.  1 ml per gallon of water for de-chlorinating so getting a litter bottle to last a while, don't have to shake before use, and at least for me, doesn't smell bad.  I use a small needless syringe with ml/cc marked to easily dose.  Can be used to de-tox ammonia or nitrite but takes a larger dosage per gallon.Will be buying the 2 liter size to last me a longer bit.

Overall , I love SeaChem prime!Aside for their rapidly fluctuating prices for the 3 different sized bottles, I think this product works well.Cleans tap water from chlorines and chloramines + locks up ammonia for 2 days or so.
summary: Product seems to be working great! My fish are living :D

reviewText: Pretty much the gold standard for dechlorinator. Added benefit of detoxifying ammonia. Note, it is only detoxified for 24-48 hours. It is not removed, it is made harmless to fish. I currently do daily dosing to be safe. Bacteria and plants can still use it in the detoxified state, so it does not stall a nitrogen cycle. Emergency nitrite dosing is also a great feature, but do not depend on that to save your fish during the cycle. Do a fishless cycle, do it right.
Used it since i started a new tank, works well. The ammonia feature works somewhat, it seems to improve the fish coat. Removes chlorine well never had a chlorine problem while using this.

I've been using Prime for quite a while now and it seems to be working out for me. When I first started out with my tanks I was using "Jungle" water conditioner and it seemed to do it's job but I wanted something more "top of the line" if you will. I didn't make the switch because I thought the "Jungle" product was inferior but I just wanted the "best" for my fish. I started researching about the best water conditioner and everyone kept raving about "Prime" they would talk about how affordable it was and the benefits that came from using this product. It seemed like the best choice for me so I made the switch I did notice that the stuff is very strong and concentrated so it doesn't take much to treat your water. As far as dosing Prime you just need to follow the instructions on the back of the bottle. I'm usually careful when I dose with Prime because of it's potency so when I prepare my water in a 5 gallon bucket I usually dose 2 drops per gallon. The reason I do it this way is because I don't want to overdose on Prime I rather be safe than sorry. With that said when I first started dosing with Prime I would dose it straight into the bucket of water. Then I would siphon the water into my tank without letting the water age. I started noticing that every time after I did a water change my fish would start gulping for air at the surface. I started reading certain threads and some people stated that in some cases too much Prime can cause oxygen depletion. Seachem has stated that you can overdose Prime about 5x the recommended dosage and it still would be safe for fish. I personally wouldn't take the risk especially if you don't have proper aeration in your tank. I know most people will say that it doesn't matter if you let your water age or if you wait for the water conditioner to take effect (since it works instantly) and they might be right but in my situation it seems to make a difference. I let my water age for about 24 hours and I sometimes even dose the water before letting it age. I also give the water a little stir just to make sure everything is mixed up well I'm not sure if it helps but I do it regardless. I've noticed that after doing all of the above my fish don't gasp for air anymore and they don't seem to be bothered at all by weekly water changes. The only downside to my method would be that the agents that lock down ammonia, nitrites and nitrates to something less toxic wouldn't really be taking effect. These locking agents stop working after 24 hours or 48 hours depending on how much you dose. I'm not too worried about it though because I keep my tanks fairly clean and I methodically keep up with my water changes. Be warned that Prime does not get rid of ammonia, nitrites or nitrates for good it just converts it to something less toxic which then allows your biological filtration to clean it up for a short period of time. Like I stated before Prime only takes effect for a brief moment and once it stops working the toxins that were locked down are released back into your water. That's where regular water changes come into play having clean water and using Prime in conjunction will definitely work to your advantage. I would say that in laymen terms Prime is a good water dechlorinator that happens to come with a few extra's. Would I say it's worth making the switch? I wouldn't really be able to answer that question because there are a lot of great products out in the market that work similar if not the same as Prime. I would however say that from a personal stand point Prime is a great product and it works very well and if used correctly it can be very effective and affordable at the same time.

my tap water is so horrible, I wouldn't drink it if I didn't have to spend money and leave the house to buy water that won't slowly kill me.Add some prime, and boom my water is safe to breathe.Nitrite or ammonia spike? Add prime, and BOOM, my fish aren't breathing toxic chemicals.
good value for the buck.  this conditioner last a long time too.  you only need a tiny bit for each gallon of water

I have quite a few tanks ranging from 5 gallons to 65 gallons. Our local water supply likes to juice up the lines with ammonia every now and then to clean them. This much to my dismay almost killed my entire tank of breeder cichlids. This stuff is way better than anything out there and keeps it all humming along happily with the oodles of water changes I do.I've used them all...this works best and I notice the least amount of disruption to the cycle of the tank and the overall happiness of the fish.
good stuff from what i hear its the best you can buy just dont use to much or to little
Great for use with fish or amphibians.  Easy to measure and conditions water for use. Removes ammonia and chloramine. Yummy!
summary: Great for use with fish or amphibians

reviewText: Good price for 100ml and way cheaper than local.  A little Prime goes a long way (I use 2 drops per gallon of water).  I use it to de-chlorinate new water for both my fresh and salt tanks and when adding new inhabitants to a system.  I've never used it to bring down ammonia/nitrite levels but knowing I have something that could double as a reducer in case of an emergency is nice.
summary: A little goes a long way

reviewText: Does everything it says. I have no chlorine but my well water has metals. I use it to condition my water. Had a little cloudiness when I first set up (new tank syndrome) but the addition of Prime cleared it up. The choice of hobbyist and professional.

Must have product for all aquariums!!! The label / bottle might not look as appealing as other branded aquarium pharmaceuticals (ie. TetraFin etc.) but the product works wonders. One thing for sure is, when using this product you might show false positives in your test kits, however, do not be alarmed if you see high Ammonia / Trite / Trate readings, this product simply detoxes these for up to 24-48 hours to make it safe for fish. To get proper readings, just perform water changes weekly.Just as a tip, I use Prime to help me with my fish in cycles.NOTE: FISHLESS CYCLES ARE ALWAYS RECOMMENDED, IT IS LESS CRUEL FOR THE FISH AND WILL GIVE YOU AN ADDED BENEFIT OF FULLY STOCKING AN AQUARIUM.

I have 4 fish tanks that house 2 african dwarf frogs, 3 male bettas and 4 females bettas. I add prime every time I clean their tanks. I use this water conditioner to help remove harmful chemicals from their water to make it safe for them. It also detoxifies nitrates and nitrites. I love  prime and will continue to use it for my fish/frogs to help keep them healthy. Highly recommend.

The things Seachem Prime can do are amazing. I highly recommend this product for anyone in fishkeeping as it is a great dechlorinator that also changes any ammonia in the tank to its non-toxic form. I have been using it during my fish-in cycle and everybody is doing very well. The concentrated nature is also really useful, as this 100mL bottle lasted me as long for my 20g (including daily half doses) as a regular dechlorinator did for a 2g.I do recommend getting pipettes or some other way to use a dropper. Dose 2 drops/gal for dechlorination/adding new water. Dose 1 drop/gal daily until ammonia disappears for fish-in cycling.
It does a great job on treating tap water.The smell of this stuff is not great, but goes away after the water is treated.
It does what it's supposed to very well. I use it in conjunction with regenerating Purigen. I highly recommend both.
Make sure you dissolve it before adding it to your tank to prevent plant melting, and your fish eating it. It works well and my pH has been very stable since using it.
summary: works well, can be hard to dissolve

reviewText: Use this with every water change as recommended by a fish expert.  Keeps the PH at the right level, been using for years.  Best thing is the price was great through Amazon.

I have tried several items to keep my tanks in balance due to the very high ph (8.4) that comes out of our faucets. This is the only product that has ever been able to keep my ph down and stable. Ever since I started using this about 2 years ago my fish have never been happier (several even started breeding on a regular basis now that the water parameters were correct). All I do is add this to my tanks when I do a water change and it makes the tap water safe and balances the ph level for me.
summary: the only one I will ever use!

reviewText: I have used this stuff for decades. I just add about 1 cup or so when I top off with a gallon of fresh water and keeps tank clean untilk I need to re-top

Neutral Regulator adjusts pH to neutral (pH 7.0) from either a low or high pH and maintains it there.It removes any chlorine, chloramine or ammonia, making other conditioning chemicals unnecessary; which, saves me time and money!Neutral regulator is the only water-conditioning product I will use.If you want to lower the pH below 7.0 you can use Seachem's Neutral Regulator with Acid Regulator or Discus Buffer; or to raise pH above 7.0 you can use with Alkaline Regulator.Seachem has terrific products for all kinds of aquarium needs.I've been depending on Seachem products for healthy aquariums for 15 years.Now, I buy the large sizes! :)
summary: Seachem's Neutral Regulator does it all!

reviewText: This will help with tropical fish that needs low Ph in water.Your tap water will be around 7.8 to 8.0 straight from faucet.this product is gaureented to reduce that to 7.0.no more need to say.so if your tropical fish needs low Ph to start with,then use this.you can even use this with discus buffer to lower it to 5.0 for sensitive fish.you can get fishes to breed with correct Ph.that is a bonus.

I have been using this product for over two years to maintain the pH in two aquariums.  It is reliable and maintains a neutral pH as advertised.  Works best if mixed into new water in a jug or bucket prior to adding to your tank for a water change.  Highly recommend!

I purchased the bigger version for my own tanks, this smaller container was sent to my mother. It removes the tannins extremely quickly and makes the water crystal clear. I absolutely LOVE this stuff for my cichlid tanks and had to send it to my mom for her tanks!
summary: Works great for removing tannins and makes the water sparkling clear!

reviewText: It works very well in pulling impurities out of the water. It turns a very dark brown after a couple months. It's reusable and it has made my water crystal clear.

While this stuff is a bit on the pricey end to get started I have found that it does in fact add an extra visible filtering boost to my tank. The regeneration process is not very expensive and extends the life of the purgien as well. This contain comes with the purigen loose and requires a purchase of "The Bag" to hold the media as most other bags are not woven small enough to not let the media slip through. I have a single turtle and a few guppies in my tank and found that I had to run more purigen than recommended to see a difference. I'm currently keeping 350ml in my 55 gallon tank at any given time and there is a noticeable difference in water clarity.
My test results are very good ever since I use purigen. I also use activated carbon and Matrix to keep my water crystal clear.

As I have come to expect form Seachem, this is another great product. It does exactly what it says it does. It gathers nitrates and nitrites from the water. This 250ml container has the loose chemical in it. (very tiny grit) You will need to purchase "the bag" by seachem. "the bag" has the perfect size bleach proof, non matalic mesh along with a resusable zip tie. Yes resusable, its pretty awesome. I have the 100ml premade bag in all my small tanks (30gal and under), and "the bag" with 250ml in my 75 gal reef tank. After about 4 months it started to turn light brown. You can let it get dark brown or even black, but I went ahead and recharged it per the instructions.(soak in in bleach water then nuturalize in prime water, the instructions are included) It worked great, the product is bright white just like when it was new. I'm not 100% sure how many times you can recharge it but a friend of mine just buys new ones every 6 months to a year. For what it does, it is dirt cheap. There are people out there that say this doesn't work so I put it to the test. I took the 250ml bag of purigen out of my sump. I then squeezed every drop I could out of it into a skinny tall glass (triple shot glass). I did this so I could insert my test strip. Right before I tested the shot glass water I tested my tank water - ammonia 0, nitrates 0, nitrites 5. Then I tested the shot glass with the squeezed purigen water - ammonia 0, nitrates 2, nitrites 50. Yes 50! that's in the deadly level. I'm an engineer not a chemist but that seems to prove to me that it is doing what it says. I expected nitrites, but I would have assumed that the nitrates would have been zero as well. It may have been when I added 5 chromis at once and a little bit of nitrates got soaked up before the bacteria caught up to convert it, don't know but it works.
summary: great product, I put it to the test and proved it works

reviewText: I Have been using this product for a few months now. I have not had the results the media is claiming to do. My Nitrates and Phosphates continue to be a problem in both my salt and fresh water tanks. I understand every tank has a different personality and I probably need to use this product along with others possibly. It seemed like this would be all I need along with my normal maintenance.

I have two goldfish in a 20 gallon and the bio load was ridiculous.  My parms were off the charts.  Ammonia and Nitrate was so high I was doing partial water changes daily to keep up.  I was using ceramic, charcoal, and sponge in an Aqua Clear 30.  Water was always cloudy.  So I bought a nylon sock from the store and filled it with about 4 tablespoons of Purigen.  I now run ceramic, Purigen, with a small amount of charcoal in a separate bag under the nylon, and foam.  The first day I didn't notice a difference in cloudiness but I did notice my fish were more active.  My fancy tail which usually just stayed at the top was swimming about.  The next day when I woke up it was magic.  I had some algae on my plants, it was literally peeling off in sheets!  The water was not cloudy at all!  Day three, filter sucked up sheet algae that was shloffing off and my water was so clear I could see the glass on the outside needed cleaning!  So I did a water test.  Ammonia 0, Nitrates, 0, Nitrates under 10ppm.  That is almost a complete 360!  My fish are happy, my plants are happy, I am happy.Please note, when I bought this I also changed from AquaSafe to Prime.  Purigen will need to be recharged every couple of months.  Using bleach then Prime.  I also added Prime to my Goldfish tank when switching to Purigen.  Both are made by Seachem.  I can not say 100% if it was my just using the Purigen or if it was the two together that changed my tank.  I highly suggest both in unison.  Now using in my nano with the same results.  Will be using in my SW tank as well.  I did not buy their "The Bag" instead opting for a white nylon you can buy at Walmart or the like.
Exactly what I thought I was getting, works well. Do NOT put loose in the water. It will float away and make a mess. Best stuff for filtration.

About 4 months ago I picked up the 250ml size Purigen and a "The Bag" just to have them handy (much like a fire extinguisher.)Fast-forward to about a month ago when I noticed a rapidly-growing bright green (bacteria? algae?) unwanted guest in my 36 gallon planted tank.So I set about to make war on this organism by doing more-than-usual water changes, and running my UV Green Killing Machine. Things were coming along nicely until I noticed one of my algae-feeding  Bamboo (Fan) shrimp had stopped eating. So was this his dislike of the green algae, or what? I had noticed that both Bamboo shrimp did not like it when I ran the UV machine a lot, so could have been that.BUT- a week went by and he's still not "fanning". Ruh-roah Roarge.Stopped the water changes, turned off the UV machine, made no difference. One of the shrimp is eating, the other is just in the cave, sitting there, day after day.Just for the heck of it I did a test for ammonia, and to my shock, it was about .75 to 1 PPM, which is WAY too high; it has always tested at "0" once the tank got established. I had evidently diminished the nitrifying bacteria and the ammonia was making the shrimp ill.Out came the Purigen, placed 125ml into Seachem's "The Bag", a quick rinse, and into the Cascade 700 GPH filter it went. Within the hour the non-eating Bamboo shrimp was out and "fanning" like he should be.The next day my ammonia level had dropped to .25 PPM.If you don't have any toxic problems now it might not be a bad idea to have some of this on hand. And if ammonia is out-of-spec I can say from experience this stuff works, and FAST.

I had issues with wood tanned water, this polished my water great, crystaline water. You will need to get "The Bag" since purigen is very fine (almost powder) or some type of fine mesh bag. Regeneration is simple just make sure to use good declorinator before putting back into tank. Highly recomended.
Worth a try I like the fact that on the bottle it tells you how to re use it ...ez way to add more surface area to your tank ...ThoseFishGeeks .com

My water in my tank has never been so good.  It is clear and the fish are healthy.  I was having a lot of trouble and losing fish.  I put this in the filters and, along with regular partial water changes, I have had a stable tank for many months now.  I don't understand the chemistry, but I can follow direction.  I have recharged it a couple times, too.  That worked well.Make sure you don't use StressCoat stuff with this as it will render it useless.  Get Seachem's Prime instead.  I use several Seachem products and they all seem to be great.
summary: This is a bottle of witchcraft

reviewText: My water was pretty clear prior to purchasing this product, though not as clear as it is now.  My main problem was trying to control the nitrites in my tank.  Admittedly, in addition to having a tank which is overstocked with Blue Rams, Bolivian Rams and Cories, I have been a little generous with the feedings.  I started to notice a lot of fish stress and then, of course, fish loss and I tested my water.  Being that I hadn't tested in about three months, I found everything to be askew.  After about a week of research and implementation, I got everything under control except my nitrites.  My nitrites were pretty high.  I cut back drastically on the feedings and implemented a few other suggestions, but nothing seemed to get them under control.  I did some research and found out about this product.  I saw the great reviews and decided to give it a try.  It took a few days, but now, my nitrites are down to zero, where they should be.  I learned a valuable lesson about fishkeeping and found a great product for my aquarium.  I will never be without it and I will test my water frequently.  I'm only sorry that my fish had to suffer for the sake of my education.
im not sure if im sold on this product.  it does seems to be doing something.  im just not so sure its as grand as some have made it out to be.  my nitrates have not gone done much with this item

I have a 250 gal. tank and several other smaller tanks with a heavy bioloads. The 250 gal. tank has a very large turtle in it. This tank's water would have a slight yellow cast to it, even after a major filter and water change. I was spending all my spare time cleaning the tanks! Purigen has kept my tank's water is clear; my turtle and tankmates are healthy and thriving.Warning, amine based slime coat products, will cause Purigen to become toxic so be certain of the type of declorinator and other chemicals you use in your aquarium do not have amine base to it.  I recommend using Seachem Prime to remove chlorine, chloramines, ammonia and nitrates.You will need to get a very fine mesh media bag to put the Purigen in as the particles are very small and most media bag's mesh are too large. Using panty hose is messy, as the particles will come out as you touch the "bag".Purigen really works great, it is worth the money, time and effort to have in your tank filter system if you like a sparkling clear and clean tank.

i had smaller tanks with a small bioload.  it gave my fish finrot. in the other tank i didnt have it in there as long and the finrot isnt as bad.didnt have issues before adding purigen.i tested my water and it was fine. it seems that whatever it did to my water, there wasnt a test for it.my once beautiful fish are now raggy ;[maybe just get this stuff if you have a big bioload and a messy tank.i just wanted a filter media that i wouldnt have to keep repurchasing.this is an expensive purchase for me since i've bought the purigen and several extra bags for it.

I use it in a 29gal biocube reef system so I "shouldn't" have any ammonia and nitrites anyway.  I don't have measurable nitrate either so I assume the purigen is doing its job.  Water is also very clear.

This is a great filtration medium that cleared up my take in a day after brown water caused by driftwood.  The water is crystal clear and I go at least 3 months without opening my canister filter to recharge (Fluval 306 on a 29 gallon tank lightly stocked).  Beware that you must use Seachem "The Bag" to avoid the Purigen beads from escaping from the filter.  Other aftermarket bags won't contain them.  I'd highly recommend this to avoid the downsides of carbon.
great product and the fact that it can be recharged is a great idea. However because you have to use bleach. be careful it will raise the PH in your tank.

Use this in my XP3 on a 65G.  For the bulk just use a mesh bag or some old pantyhose.Pros:- Renewable- Easy to tell when it needs to be cleaned- Much cheaper than carbon because you can re-use itCons:- Fine pellets can be messy so be careful!

Seachem Purigen 100% Excellent.Excellent product, has come fast and super fast timePerforms work perfectly for Marine Aquariums and Sweets. Purchase a bag and add only necessary according to the number of liters of your aquarium and place in a recirculation pump (in my case Cascada) ufsss. trabjo doing very well.When changes color (brown) and dark can replace or just clean the aquarium water look a container (1 liter) leaves the bag to soak and add 10 drops of PRIME. for 24 hours. ready again to pump ..Easy, simple and uncomplicated. perform their measurements of ammonium, nitrite and NITRATE with API test

This stuff is amazing.  It polishes the water very well and makes it look crystal clear.  I would have given 5 stars, but you are forced to buy "The Bag" which is a filter media bag from Seachem.  The reason for this is, is that the Purigen is very very FINE (almost like sand) and will seep through most media storage devices.  You might be able to try panty hose, but I wouldn't recommend it.It is also very easy to use.  Just dump it into "The Bag" from Seachem, zip tie it up, rinse it with some filtered watered (can probably use tap water, but that makes me nervous.  I might be weird on this one, but tap water makes me nervous in general so whenever I'm using tap water or even filtered water, I dump some prime in the tank, Once rinsed just put it in your filter.I currently have this in 2 HOB filters and it works amazing.  I have a third that I am going to put in one of my canisters, but I have been too lazy to tear my canister apart.Also I have been using for a month now in a planted tank that I dose with Excel and the Purigen has had no ill effects on the plantsExcellent Product that I would recommend!!  They also say it is rechargeable!!!  Wish I learned about this stuff sooner!
So far so good I have it in my tank now while it cycles and its doing its thing right now I actually like it along with chemipure elite great combo
These little are guys are really small. you will have to buy the bag that goes with this. "The Bag" from Seachem
combined with Seachem Bag Filter, my tank has been much more stable and therefore easier to clean,  Not as worried about crashing the nitro-cycle.
Not sure this is even working, but the water is infact clearer then it has ever been before.  Dont regret the purchase but not sure its working.

Its supposed to be a good filtration product, but make sure you use it with the same manufacturers water conditioner.  When combined with several common chlorine remover/water conditioners it produces chlorine in great amounts.  I tried this in a test tank that was going pretty well and it killed 3 of the 4 fish before I figured out what was wrong, and it happened in just a few hours.Otherwise the concept is good...the product shlorks up organic waste and when it turns black you soak it in bleach which kills off everything it sucked up, and then you treat it with the chlorine remover sold by the same company, then its good to absorb bad stuff for another month or two.  Just be careful to research which chemicals you're using and make sure they wont cause harm.
summary: Be very careful with this stuff

reviewText: This product has been by far the most helpfull in keeping sparkling clear water. I use it instead of activated charcoal in my planted tanks. The charcoal has a tendancy to remove suppliments quickly as does the purigen, BUT, purigen seems to add balance and the clarity is unmistakeable. With suppliments going into the aqauriums daily this has not effected my plants or water chemistry. Super product.

the good: this stuff will make your water amazingly clear, it is literally the best filter media i have ever used. it removed wood tannins, discoloration, everything from every tank i've used it in.the bad: it is very small. either order VERY fine mesh bags, and maybe double bag it, or order the purigen item "the bag" which is purigen already in it's own bag. do  not let this small point put you off. this stuff is great!

These amazing beads really clean up my aquarium tank to a clear crystal quality.  It would be nice though if the manufacturer had included instructions on how to clean and recycle the beads (I had to call customer service to find out).  Also a pouch to put this stuff in would be nice.  Tried it with my wife's old nylon panty hose; after several uses, the nylon breaks up due to the bleaching agent required for cleaning.  Overall though, the product is truly amazing.  I gave up using charcoal filter altogether.  Your fish will be happy too.
Definitely a must for fish like Cichlids or Goldfish.. all my numbers are just right and all i have to do is weekly water changes by choice. :)
This product complies exactly what it promises. My fish are healthy and vibrant colors. The Seachem products are excellent. Recommend the use of this product.
Great product, I have been using it for many years, have not lost a fish yet due to water problems.

I highly recommend Seachem's Cichlid Lake Salt.  It is essential in duplicating the native waters of African Cichlid's.  In my opinion, this is a quality product, reasonably priced, and I do not know of a equal product.

We have had a 38 gallon cichlid tank for awhile now.  We keep losing fish.  A friend gave us a 46 gallon tank and we decided to move the cichlids to the bigger tank.  We decided that this time, we were going to do it right.  We used cichlid sand and this cichlid salt.  When we went to test the water before putting the fish in, everything was right on.  The first 6 fish have been in the new tank for 5 days now and are doing well.  No casualties from the move, and their colors are so much brighter.  Our orange fish is bright neon now, and the yellow fish are so much brighter, too!  In another 5 days or so, we'll add the rest of the cichlids to the new tank.  I'm so glad that we bought this salt.
If you keep your cichlids in somewhat brackish water this is your product it is made for them and it is easy disolvePlus its not standard table salt
purchase this to slightly salt my fresh water tank and the fish love it, helps to keep their skin slimy and makes them more colorful
Since adding the recommended dose of this salt, my fish seems to be happier and more friendly. As an added bonus my plants seem more vibrant. Perhaps a shortage of some mineral?
summary: My fish and my plants seem to appreciate this stuff.

reviewText: I use it, don't know if the fish care for it one way or another, but I use it.  Everyone says to use it, so I use it.
The best salt for your cichlid's, been using it for years and will keep using it, check Ebay for better pricing but the product works great, I always have 2 on hand, thank you.

I like having the mid sized bottle. The small bottle goes to quick, the big one is overkill, unless you have bunch of big Malawi tanks. This one is great, last long enough that I'm not having to get a new one every few months. It is the right salt for Malawi and Tangynika cichlids. There are trace minerals in here that keep everything looking good and staying healthy.
summary: Get it if you have African cichilds

reviewText: A 40 year fan keeping and breeding African Cichlids and a long time fan of SeaChem products these salts are excellent at maintaning the right water parameters in which these gorgeous fish thrive at their best. My Red Devils, Frontosas and FlowerHorns most of which are full grown and in huge seperate tanks owe much of their long term success to SeaChem products, especially the Trace Elements product by SeaChem.Please be aware that once you start using this product it's imperative that durng water changes the same dilution and ration of going maintained, especially when adding new water via water changes. It's a commitment and an on going investment in this product. I find now, I use these salts for newly cycled tanks, QT and hospital tanks. I have a few tanks that recieve the salts on a regular basis. The reason for this has zero to do with cost, this an affordalble product - goes a long way.That said because you want to keep your PH at the same reading as you blood,that crushed coral exceptional buffer. CaribSea has excellent crushed coral, add it to your filters (always use a filter bag) and you'll find it maintains the brackish high alkaline levels between 8.5 - 10It's perfectly fine to use both an internal or in tank buffer like crushed coral along with the salts, just check your PH more than usual as you may need to adjust the volume of one or the other.The price offered here on Amazon is the best I've seen and will be ordering here from now on.

A must have for Cichlids.  Helps keep parasites and fugal infections down and the fish thrive when you dose properly.  Just be sure to dissolve before you add it to your tank. :)  I buy this in bulk.  I use it often and it's worth every penny.

Doesn't do anything, I add one cap full twice a week for my forty six bow and the plants are just turning brown and dieing, will by leafzone next time that stuff works and makes them thrive, now I'm out the price of this bottle and eleven bucks in plants. Live and learn
summary: Buy leaf zone goe's quicker but works this is waste of money, I will try doubling dose.

reviewText: Arrived in a timely manner. One of the first liquid supplements I bought for my 5 gallon nano tank. Mainly had anubias and java fern. They were slow growers, but after using Flourish I noticed a slight increase in the growth of my plants. Cheaper and easy to dose relative to the tank size. Dosing with dry fertilizers is more cost effective in the long run and for larger tanks though.
